population_specificity: Women with breast and gynecological cancers receiving chemotherapy.
effective_dosage: Once-daily self-practice at home for 3 weeks.
study_duration: 3 weeks of intervention, with follow-up assessments at 6 weeks and 12 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of Progressive Muscle Relaxation (PMR) in reducing stress, anxiety, and depression among parents of adolescents with mental illness.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant reductions in stress and anxiety after five PMR sessions, and further significant reductions in depression, anxiety, and stress after ten sessions. The PMR program was highly effective in improving mental health outcomes for the studied population.
population_specificity: Parents of adolescents with mental illness.
effective_dosage: Ten sessions of Jacobson PMR (specific duration per session not mentioned).
study_duration: Intervention spanned ten sessions (total duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether progressive muscle relaxation affects anxiety and depression levels in pregnant women, as well as pregnancy outcomes, labor pain, and analgesic requirements.
results_summary: Progressive muscle relaxation significantly reduced depression levels and trait anxiety during puerperium, though no differences were found in pregnancy outcomes, labor pain, or analgesic requirements overall. Women attending more than five sessions reported significantly less labor pain compared to controls.
population_specificity: 156 pregnant women in a prospective non-randomized controlled cohort study.
effective_dosage: Once a week for six weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding progressive muscle relaxation (PMR) to pulmonary rehabilitation (PR) improves mental health and physical outcomes in patients with long-term COVID-19 symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that PR combined with PMR significantly improved mental health outcomes (anxiety, sleep quality, and overall well-being) compared to PR alone, though exercise capacity improvements were similar between groups. PMR enhanced non-physical recovery aspects in long COVID-19 patients.
population_specificity: 61 patients with long-term COVID-19 symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of Progressive Muscle Relaxation (PMR) in improving the well-being of dementia caregivers by reducing anxiety, stress, depression, and caregiver burden.
results_summary: The study found that PMR significantly reduced anxiety, stress, depression, and caregiver burden among participants. Female caregivers and those under financial stress showed higher levels of distress and burden.
population_specificity: Caregivers of individuals with dementia (n = 57).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of progressive muscle relaxation exercises (PMRE) on breastfeeding success and breastfeeding self-efficacy in primiparous women after cesarean section.
results_summary: PMRE significantly improved breastfeeding success and self-efficacy compared to the control group, with a 74.7% and 88.1% increase, respectively, though NLP showed slightly higher efficacy.
population_specificity: Primiparous women who gave birth by cesarean section (n=33 in PMRE group).
effective_dosage: Applied every eight hours for 48 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of sleep hygiene and progressive muscle relaxation (SH & PMR) versus an occlusal device (OD) on perceived stress and sleep bruxism activity in individuals with sleep bruxism.
results_summary: SH & PMR significantly reduced bruxism episodes/hour and bursts/episode at all follow-ups and decreased perceived stress scores, though the decrease was not statistically significant compared to the OD group. Both interventions were safe and effective for managing sleep bruxism and stress.
population_specificity: 66 participants with self-reported sleep bruxism.
study_duration: 1 year (assessed at baseline, 1 month, 6 months, and 1 year)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of progressive muscle relaxation in reducing stress, anxiety, and depression levels in adolescents.
results_summary: The study found a statistically significant reduction in stress, anxiety, and depression levels in adolescents who underwent progressive muscle relaxation compared to the control group. The intervention group showed improved post-test scores after correcting for baseline differences.
population_specificity: 12th-grade students from two high schools in Turkiye.
effective_dosage: Online progressive muscle relaxation sessions over eight weeks (specific frequency not mentioned).

study_goal: To examine the effects of Jacobson's Progressive Muscle Relaxation Technique (JPMRT) on menstrual pain, symptoms, anxiety, quality of life, social activity, and work/school performance in women with primary dysmenorrhea.
results_summary: JPMRT significantly reduced menstrual pain intensity, symptoms, anxiety, and improved quality of life, social activity, and work/school performance compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Women with primary dysmenorrhea.
study_duration: From the estimated date of ovulation to the onset of the next menstruation.

study_goal: To determine the effect of mindfulness meditation combined with progressive muscle relaxation training on clinical efficacy and quality of life in sarcopenia patients receiving maintenance haemodialysis.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant improvements in exercise capacity, quality of life dimensions, and inflammatory markers compared to the control group. No adverse effects were reported, but safety was not explicitly assessed.
population_specificity: Patients with sarcopenia receiving maintenance haemodialysis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of Progressive Muscle Relaxation (PMR) on anxiety levels and sleep quality in healthcare practitioners managing COVID-19 patients in a mobile cabin hospital.
results_summary: PMR significantly improved sleep quality (reduced PSQI scores) and reduced anxiety (lower HAMA scores) among healthcare practitioners, with detection rates of poor sleep and anxiety states decreasing post-intervention.
population_specificity: Healthcare practitioners managing COVID-19 patients in a mobile cabin hospital.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of progressive muscle relaxation (PMR) exercises on vital signs and fatigue in kidney transplant patients.
results_summary: PMR exercises reduced pulse rate, body temperature, and arterial blood pressure while increasing oxygen saturation in kidney transplant patients. The exercises also significantly decreased fatigue in the intervention group compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Kidney transplant patients at a university hospital in Turkey (n=52, intervention=26, control=26).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how progressive muscle relaxation affects dyspnea, pain, and sleep quality in lung cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in dyspnea, pain, and sleep quality in the intervention group, with moderate to large effect sizes. Progressive muscle relaxation was particularly effective for dyspnea and sleep quality.
population_specificity: Seventy-four lung cancer patients receiving chemotherapy.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes per session, 2 days a week for 8 weeks (16 sessions total).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of progressive muscle relaxation exercises (PMRE) on sleep quality in chemotherapy patients experiencing disturbed sleep.
results_summary: The study found that PMRE significantly improved sleep quality, as evidenced by lower PSQI Global and subdimension scores in the intervention group compared to the control group (P < .001). The intervention was particularly effective in reducing sleep latency, improving subjective sleep quality, and decreasing daytime dysfunction.
population_specificity: Cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy with poor sleep quality.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Progressive Muscle Relaxation (PMR) in reducing symptoms of premenstrual syndrome (PMS) and associated depression, anxiety, and stress in university students.
results_summary: The study found that PMR, both alone and in combination with yoga, significantly reduced PMS symptoms and lowered depression, anxiety, and stress scores compared to the control group. The effects were statistically significant (p < .05).
population_specificity: University students with premenstrual syndrome (PMS).
study_duration: Data collected between April 2022 and June 2022 (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of Jacobson's Progressive Muscle Relaxation (JPMR) on reducing anxiety and promoting happiness in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that JPMR significantly reduced anxiety (p < 0.001) and increased happiness (p < 0.001) in older adults after the intervention.
population_specificity: Older adults living in a nursing home in Rasht, Iran (n=34).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically compile evidence on the efficacy of Progressive Muscle Relaxation (PMR) in reducing stress, anxiety, and depression in adults globally.
results_summary: The study found that PMR is effective in reducing stress, anxiety, and depression in adults, with enhanced efficacy when combined with other interventions. The results were consistent across 46 publications covering over 3402 adults from 16 countries.
population_specificity: Adults (over 3402 participants from 16 countries)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Progressive Muscle Relaxation (PMR) in reducing cancer-related pain and improving pain interference with life activities in palliative care patients.
results_summary: The study found that PMR significantly reduced pain intensity and improved pain interference with general activity, mood, relations with others, sleep, and enjoyment of life compared to the control group at both the end of the intervention and 1-month follow-up.
population_specificity: 148 cancer patients receiving palliative care.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of online health training/counseling and progressive muscle relaxation exercises on postpartum depression and maternal attachment.
results_summary: The study found that the intervention significantly reduced postpartum depression (EPDS scores) and improved maternal attachment (MPAS scores) compared to the control group. The experimental group showed a mean EPDS score of 3.40 post-intervention versus 11.40 in the control group (P < 0.05).
population_specificity: Pregnant women at 35 weeks gestation, stratified by EPDS scores and parity.
effective_dosage: Progressive muscle relaxation exercises were performed from 36 weeks of pregnancy until 6 months postpartum, with online counseling provided throughout.
study_duration: From 36 weeks of pregnancy until 6 months postpartum.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining slow breathing exercises (SBE) and progressive muscle relaxation (PMR) could effectively reduce blood pressure, heart rate, respiratory rate, and anxiety in patients with essential hypertension compared to using either technique alone.
results_summary: The study found that combined SBE-PMR interventions significantly reduced heart rate, respiratory rate, blood pressure, and anxiety in hypertensive patients compared to standalone techniques, with most outcomes showing statistically significant improvements. PMR alone also showed benefits, though some comparisons with combined interventions were insignificant.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with essential hypertension (64 participants, 16 per group).
effective_dosage: Not specified (only mentions different treatments per group).
study_duration: 4 weeks (measurements at baseline, 2nd week, and 4th week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of internet-delivered short-term Progressive Muscle Relaxation (iPMR) and psychoeducation on mindful ability, visceral hypersensitivity, and gastrointestinal symptoms in patients with IBS.
results_summary: The iPMR group showed significant increases in mindful ability and significant decreases in visceral hypersensitivity and gastrointestinal symptoms compared to the psychoeducation group, with effects sustained at follow-up.
population_specificity: 60 patients with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the feasibility, acceptability, and preliminary effects of combining music intervention with progressive muscle relaxation on anxiety, depression, stress, and quality of life in breast and gynecological cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy.
results_summary: The intervention group showed greater reductions in anxiety, depression, and stress, as well as improved quality of life compared to the control group at post-intervention and follow-up. Participants reported perceived beneficial effects on psychological and physical health and expressed willingness to continue practicing the intervention.
population_specificity: Women with breast and gynecological cancer receiving chemotherapy in Vietnam.
effective_dosage: Daily self-practice at home for three weeks (specific duration per session not specified).
study_duration: 3 weeks of intervention, with follow-up at 6 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether progressive muscle relaxation (PMR) combined with sleep hygiene training (SH) improves sleep, ADHD symptoms, and related outcomes in children with ADHD compared to SH alone.
results_summary: The study found that SH + PMR led to significant improvements in selective attention, peer problems, and anxiety scores compared to SH alone, while both interventions improved sleep, ADHD symptoms, functioning, and parental sleep quality.
population_specificity: Children aged 6-12 years with ADHD.
effective_dosage: Not specified (group training + 8 weeks of telephone interviews).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of progressive muscle relaxation, meditation, and mental practice-based interventions on chronic right upper extremity tremor in a patient post-traumatic brain injury.
results_summary: The patient showed improvements in quality of life, tremor severity, tremor impact on daily activities, motor function, tremor frequency, and spirograph performance. The combination of interventions positively impacted tremor across physical and psychosocial domains.
population_specificity: A 47-year-old male with a traumatic brain injury and chronic right upper extremity tremor.
effective_dosage: Weekly in-person sessions and daily home practice (specific duration per session not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of transdiagnostic therapy and Progressive Muscle Relaxation (PMR) on emotion regulation, self-compassion, maternal role adaptation, and social/work adjustment in mothers of premature infants.
results_summary: PMR showed some effectiveness but was significantly less effective than transdiagnostic therapy in improving emotion regulation, self-compassion, maternal role adaptation, and social/work adjustment at post-test and follow-up (p < 0.01).
population_specificity: Mothers of premature infants (n=14 in the PMR group).
study_duration: Duration of intervention not specified (eight sessions conducted).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Progressive Muscle Relaxation (PMR) in reducing perioperative anxiety, stress, and pain, and improving lumbar function in patients with lumbar disc herniation after surgery.
results_summary: PMR significantly reduced perioperative anxiety and stress, lowered heart rate and systolic blood pressure before surgery, and improved lumbar function and pain scores compared to conventional intervention alone. The PMR group showed greater reductions in pain and better functional outcomes post-surgery.
population_specificity: 128 patients with lumbar disc herniation who underwent surgery.
study_duration: Intervention effects were measured up to 3 months post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether Progressive Muscle Relaxation (PMR) combined with mirror therapy is more effective than generic relaxation-mirror therapy or conventional physiotherapy in reducing phantom limb pain (PLP) in lower limb amputees.
results_summary: PMR-mirror therapy showed a 65% reduction in PLP rate and duration compared to generic relaxation-mirror therapy (30%) and conventional physiotherapy (6%), and a 90% reduction in PLP intensity compared to 45% and 20% in the other groups, respectively. The study suggests PMR may enhance mirror therapy's effectiveness for PLP management.
population_specificity: Thirty lower limb amputees suffering from phantom limb pain.
study_duration: 3 weeks of intervention, with follow-up 1 week post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of Progressive Muscle Relaxation (PMRT) combined with virtual reality (VR) scenarios on state anxiety and to compare its effectiveness with guided imagery and audio-track guidance.
results_summary: Preliminary data from 40 participants are being analyzed, with final results expected in June 2023. The study aims to determine if VR enhances relaxation and reduces anxiety more effectively than guided imagery or audio-based methods.
population_specificity: 108 university students

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of progressive muscle relaxation exercises on depressive symptom severity, sleep quality, and quality of life in patients with epilepsy.
results_summary: Progressive muscle relaxation exercises significantly reduced depressive symptoms and improved sleep quality and overall life quality in epilepsy patients compared to the control group. The intervention group showed statistically significant improvements in all measured outcomes (p<0.05).
population_specificity: 70 patients with epilepsy (35 intervention, 35 control).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether movement therapy combined with progressive muscle relaxation could reduce depression rates in hospitalized patients with major depression.
results_summary: The study found a statistically significant reduction in depression scores in the intervention group (8.01±5.22) compared to the control group (22.96±9.43), indicating that the combined therapy effectively reduced depression.
population_specificity: 60 hospitalized patients diagnosed with major depression, aged at least 20 years.
effective_dosage: 15 to 20 minutes of progressive muscle relaxation per session, following 30-45 minutes of movement therapy.
study_duration: 30 sessions (duration per session not specified beyond 30-45 mins for movement therapy + 15-20 mins for relaxation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Progressive Muscle Relaxation (PMR) exercises in improving mental health, sleep quality, and overall quality of life in COVID-19 patients.
results_summary: PMR interventions improved sleep quality, anxiety, depression, disease severity, and quality of life in mild to moderate COVID-19 patients compared to usual care, with only one reported adverse event.
population_specificity: Patients with mild to moderate COVID-19.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of progressive muscle relaxation on psychological (stress, anxiety, mood) and physiological (blood pressure, heart rate) variables in adolescent basketball athletes.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant reductions in cognitive anxiety and specific stress, as well as a significant decrease in heart rate in the intervention group compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 59 basketball players aged 14-19 from the Bauru Basket team.
effective_dosage: 12 progressive muscle relaxation sessions (frequency not specified).
study_duration: Duration of intervention not explicitly stated, but involved 12 sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of Progressive Muscle Relaxation on reducing stress and anxiety in nurses caring for COVID-19 patients.
results_summary: The study found that Progressive Muscle Relaxation significantly reduced stress and anxiety levels in nurses compared to the control group, with statistically significant improvements post-intervention. No significant changes were observed in the control group.
population_specificity: Nurses working in COVID-19 wards in Tehran, Iran.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether Progressive Muscle Relaxation (PMR) could modify test anxiety and attentional bias in medical students.
results_summary: PMR significantly reduced test anxiety scores post-intervention and at follow-up, though it was less effective than hypnosis. PMR did not modify attentional bias toward threatening stimuli.
population_specificity: Medical college students with high test anxiety.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Progressive Muscle Relaxation (PMRT) on symptoms and quality of life in cancer patients.
results_summary: PMRT significantly alleviated anxiety and pain, improved quality of life, and showed better effects on depression, self-esteem, nausea, and vomiting compared to controls, but no significant effect on fatigue was detected.
population_specificity: Cancer patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of progressive muscle relaxation exercise on anxiety among male nursing students undergoing maternity clinical training.
results_summary: The study found that progressive muscle relaxation significantly reduced anxiety levels among male nursing students, with a statistically significant reduction (t (47) = 21.2, p < .05) after the intervention.
population_specificity: Male nursing students enrolled in a maternity nursing course at Arab American University Palestine.
effective_dosage: Jacobson's progressive muscle relaxation exercise for five consecutive days per week.
study_duration: Five consecutive days per week (exact total duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether progressive muscle relaxation (PMR) could reduce abdominal pain and distension in colonoscopy patients.
results_summary: PMR significantly reduced post-colonoscopy abdominal pain and distension in the intervention group compared to the control group, with statistically significant improvements observed.
population_specificity: Colonoscopy patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of progressive muscle relaxation (PMR), alone or combined with health education (HE), on vasomotor symptoms and insomnia in perimenopausal women.
results_summary: PMR, both alone and combined with HE, significantly improved hot flash and night sweats frequency and severity, as well as insomnia scores, compared to the control group. The combination of PMR and HE showed greater improvement with larger effect sizes than PMR alone.
population_specificity: Perimenopausal women experiencing vasomotor symptoms and insomnia.

study_goal: To determine the effect of progressive muscle relaxation, combined with aerobic exercises and prophylactic medicine, on migraine patients.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in pain and disability measures in both groups, but the group receiving progressive muscle relaxation and aerobic exercises showed significantly better outcomes post-intervention.
population_specificity: Migraine patients aged 20-50 years, predominantly female (85.7%).
effective_dosage: Progressive muscle relaxation for 15 minutes, 3 times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of progressive muscle relaxation and deep breathing exercises on dyspnea and fatigue symptoms in COPD patients.
results_summary: The study found that progressive muscle relaxation and deep breathing exercises significantly reduced dyspnea and fatigue symptoms in COPD patients, with statistically significant improvements in the intervention group compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 116 COPD patients from a chest diseases follow-up outpatient clinic in Gaziantep, Turkey.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of Jacobson's progressive muscle relaxation technique on maternal, fetal, and neonatal outcomes in women with non-severe preeclampsia.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant improvements in systolic and diastolic blood pressure, 24-hour urine protein levels, fasting blood sugar, birth weight, fetal heart rate, and fetal movements in the intervention group compared to the control group. No significant differences were observed in the control group.
population_specificity: Women with non-severe preeclampsia in a referral center in Karaj, Iran.
effective_dosage: Twice a week for 6 weeks (4 face-to-face sessions and 8 online sessions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of expressive arts therapy combined with progressive muscle relaxation under music on anxiety and hope in patients with gynecological malignancies undergoing surgery.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant improvements in state anxiety (SAI) during preoperation and postoperation periods but no significant differences in hope (HHI) or predischarge anxiety. Most intervention participants (98%) reported subjective benefits from expressive arts therapy.
population_specificity: Patients with primary or recurrent gynecological malignancies scheduled for surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of progressive muscle relaxation exercise on anxiety levels among nursing students during pediatric nursing clinical training.
results_summary: The study found that progressive muscle relaxation significantly reduced anxiety levels in nursing students, with post-intervention scores (M = 1.34 ± 0.36) being lower than pre-intervention scores (M = 2.83 ± 0.35). The reduction was statistically significant (t (59) = 21.1, P < 0.05).
population_specificity: Nursing students enrolled in a pediatric nursing course at the Arab American University/Palestine.
effective_dosage: Jacobson's progressive muscle relaxation exercise for five consecutive days per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of an integrated intervention combining cognitive-behavioural stress management (CBSM) and progressive muscle relaxation (PMRs) on immune biomarkers, disease severity, and psychological outcomes in COVID-19 patients.
results_summary: The study found that the combined CBSM and PMRs intervention significantly improved immune biomarkers (Leucocytes, Lymphocytes, Interleukin-6, Immunoglobulin-A), reduced disease severity, and alleviated stress, anxiety, and depression in COVID-19 patients. These effects persisted for at least one week post-intervention.
population_specificity: Thirty patients with mild or moderate COVID-19.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Progressive Muscle Relaxation (PMR) could enhance slow-wave sleep (SWS) during a nap compared to an active control (listening to Mozart music).
results_summary: PMR participants spent approximately 10 minutes more in SWS (125% increase) compared to the control group, with greater right-lateralized slow-wave activity and reduced time in REM sleep. Pre-sleep anxiety levels predicted nap architecture in the PMR group, suggesting anxiety may influence benefits.
population_specificity: Healthy young adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of progressive muscle relaxation techniques on self-esteem and self-efficacy in multiple sclerosis (MS) patients.
results_summary: The study found that progressive muscle relaxation significantly improved self-esteem and self-efficacy in MS patients, with notable differences observed 4 weeks post-intervention. Self-efficacy showed immediate and sustained improvement, while self-esteem improvements became significant only after 4 weeks.
population_specificity: 100 MS patients randomly divided into experimental (n=50) and control (n=50) groups.

study_goal: To determine the effectiveness of progressive muscle relaxation (PMR) in reducing anxiety caused by Covid-19 in pregnant women.
results_summary: PMR significantly reduced anxiety in pregnant women compared to the control group, with statistically significant differences observed post-intervention and at follow-up. The intervention group showed lower anxiety scores (22.92 ± 6.07) versus the control group (28.13 ± 6.93).
population_specificity: Pregnant women under comprehensive health service centers in the nineteenth district of Tehran University of Medical Sciences.
effective_dosage: Six sessions (three times a week) of PMR training and practice.
study_duration: 2 weeks (with follow-up at 2 and 4 weeks post-baseline).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of kindergarten-based progressive muscle relaxation (PMR) on attention and executive functioning in 5-6-year-old children.
results_summary: The study found that PMR significantly improved attention, visuomotor precision, memory, and motor inhibition compared to both physical education and control groups, with no significant baseline differences.
population_specificity: 5-6-year-old children from two private Tunisian kindergartens (26 female, 26 male).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Progressive Muscle Relaxation (PMR) could reduce postoperative pain, fatigue, and improve vital signs in head and neck cancer surgery patients.
results_summary: PMR significantly reduced overall pain, muscle tightness, sleep disturbances, fatigue, anxiety, and depression compared to the control group. It also lowered respiratory rates and diastolic blood pressure.
population_specificity: Patients with head and neck cancers undergoing major surgeries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether progressive muscle relaxation exercises could reduce anxiety in first-year nursing students during their initial clinical experience.
results_summary: The study found that progressive muscle relaxation significantly reduced anxiety in nursing students, as measured by the S-anxiety scale (STAI Form Y-1), with statistically significant results (t (89) = 30.783, P = .001).
population_specificity: First-year nursing students at the Arab American University.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Progressive Muscle Relaxation (PMR) improves sleep quality in patients recovering from coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery.
results_summary: The study found that PMR significantly improved overall sleep quality, subjective sleep quality, and habitual sleep efficiency compared to the control group, though no significant differences were observed in sleep latency, duration, disturbances, medication use, or daytime dysfunction.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent CABG surgery at two academic hospitals in Iran.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether progressive muscle relaxation improves sleep quality and reduces fatigue in patients with rheumatoid arthritis.
results_summary: Progressive muscle relaxation significantly reduced sleep disturbances and fatigue scores in the intervention group after 6 weeks, with no changes observed in the control group. The differences between groups were statistically significant.
population_specificity: 72 patients with rheumatoid arthritis from a university hospital rheumatology outpatient clinic.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Progressive Muscle Relaxation Therapy (PMRT) against escitalopram and placebo in reducing hot flashes in breast cancer patients.
results_summary: PMRT effectively reduced the frequency and duration of both diurnal and nocturnal hot flashes in breast cancer patients, though escitalopram showed a stronger effect. Both treatments also decreased the total score on the Menopause Rating Scale (MRS).
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with primary breast cancer.
effective_dosage: Not specified for PMRT (only escitalopram dosage mentioned: 10 mg).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of progressive muscle relaxation on state and trait anxiety levels in nursing students before their first clinical practice.
results_summary: Progressive muscle relaxation significantly reduced state anxiety levels in nursing students, but no significant difference was observed in trait anxiety levels. The control group showed no similar reduction, indicating the intervention's effectiveness.
population_specificity: Nursing students (81.4% female, mean age 19.74±1.38 years) preparing for their first clinical practice.
effective_dosage: Three times a week for the first 2 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of progressive muscle relaxation therapy (PMRT) on pain, fatigue, and stress in patients with fibromyalgia syndrome.
results_summary: PMRT significantly reduced pain, fatigue, perceived stress, systolic and diastolic blood pressure, and pulse rate compared to conventional physical therapies in fibromyalgia patients.
population_specificity: 37 patients with fibromyalgia syndrome (ages 20-65, 4 men and 33 women).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-inflammatory properties of S-adenosylmethionine (SAMe) and its interaction with Prohibitin 1 (Phb1) in modulating immune responses in macrophages.
results_summary: SAMe significantly reduced LPS-induced inflammatory responses, including IL-1β, IL-10, Nos2, and NO production, and attenuated NF-κB activation in Phb1 knockdown macrophages, suggesting anti-inflammatory effects.
population_specificity: RAW 264.7 macrophage cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to clarify the mechanisms by which S-adenosylmethionine counteracts levodopa-induced vascular endothelial growth factor-A-related effects in human umbilical vein endothelial cells.
results_summary: S-adenosylmethionine opposed levodopa's effects on angiogenesis and cell viability, induced G1/S phase arrest, and reduced vascular endothelial growth factor-A stability by enhancing its acetylation. These effects were mediated through extracellular signal-regulated kinase phosphorylation.
population_specificity: Human umbilical vein endothelial cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) as a metabolic inhibitor of autophagy and its potential regulatory effects on cellular homeostasis.
results_summary: The study found that SAM is a critical inhibitor of methionine starvation-induced autophagy, influencing epigenetic regulation and producing metabolites like homocysteine and spermidine that further modulate autophagy. SAM connects cellular metabolic status to autophagy regulation, suggesting its potential as a therapeutic target.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely in vitro or animal models based on abstract context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antitumor effects of S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) alone and in combination with anti-PD-1 antibody in a melanoma mouse model.
results_summary: SAM alone and in combination with anti-PD-1 significantly reduced tumor volumes and weights, with the combination showing the highest efficacy. The treatment altered key cancer-related pathways and enhanced CD8+ T cell activation, proliferation, and cytokine production.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 mice injected with B16-F1 melanoma cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether co-culturing rice seedlings with Chlorella sp. enhances S-adenosylmethionine-dependent methyltransferase (SAMT) gene expression to mitigate arsenic-induced toxicity.
results_summary: Co-culturing rice seedlings with Chlorella sp. enhanced SAMT gene expression, contributing to reduced arsenic toxicity by improving glutathione-dependent detoxification pathways and antioxidant enzyme activity.
population_specificity: Rice seedlings (Oryza sativa L.) exposed to arsenic stress.
effective_dosage: Not specified for S-adenosylmethionine; arsenic treatments were 60 µM As(III) and As(V).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of S-adenosylmethionine (SAMe) as monotherapy or adjunctive therapy for major depressive disorder (MDD) compared to placebo or other antidepressants.
results_summary: SAMe was significantly better than placebo in three out of five comparisons and showed no significant difference compared to other antidepressants in four comparisons. One study found SAMe accelerated response to imipramine early in treatment, and another showed SAMe combined with SSRIs was better than placebo combined with SSRIs.
population_specificity: Individuals with major depressive disorder (MDD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the metabolic flux redistribution in cells with altered S-adenosylmethionine decarboxylase (SAMdc) activity and its implications for antitumor therapy.
results_summary: The study found that SAMdc inactivation increases metabolic fluxes through methionine, taurine, glutathione synthesis, and folate cycles, suggesting potential tumor metabolism reprogramming. It also showed enhanced transformation of S-adenosylmethionine to homocysteine and methionine, along with intensified transsulfuration processes.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or cellular model implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the synergistic antitumor effects of S-adenosylmethionine (AdoMet) when combined with standard chemotherapy drugs for breast cancer and head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC).
results_summary: The study found that AdoMet, as a natural compound with pleiotropic effects, shows promise as a chemosensitizing agent, enhancing the efficacy of standard chemotherapy drugs in treating breast cancer and HNSCC. It suggests AdoMet could be integrated into emerging antitumor therapies like nanotechnologies.
population_specificity: Patients with breast cancer and head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether S-adenosylmethionine supplementation could increase protein phosphatase 2A activity, reduce phosphorylated tau levels, and improve spatial memory in rTg4510 mice.
results_summary: S-adenosylmethionine treatment increased novel arm exploration time in the Y-maze, elevated protein phosphatase 2A expression and activity, and reduced phosphorylated tau levels and AT8-positive neurons.
population_specificity: 6-month-old rTg4510 mice expressing mutant human P301L tau.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) and Vitamin D could enhance anti-cancer effects in metastatic breast cancer by targeting multiple pathways.
results_summary: SAM monotherapy significantly reduced breast cancer cell proliferation and metastasis in vitro and in vivo, with even stronger effects when combined with Vitamin D. Transcriptomic analysis showed broader impact on cancer-related pathways in the combination treatment.
population_specificity: Breast cancer cell lines and in vivo models (specific human population not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of combining SAMe (200 mg) and L. plantarum HEAL9 on mild-to-moderate depression symptoms.
results_summary: The combination significantly improved depression, anxiety, and cognitive symptoms by week 2, with sustained benefits at week 6, and no adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18-60 with mild-to-moderate depression (ICD-10 criteria).
effective_dosage: 200 mg SAMe + 1 × 10⁹ CFU L. plantarum HEAL9 daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of AhSAMDC in enhancing plant resistance to salt stress by improving polyamine content and alleviating membrane damage.
results_summary: The study found that AhSAMDC overexpression in tobacco led to higher germination rates, longer root lengths under salt stress, reduced membrane damage, increased antioxidant enzyme activity, and higher proline and polyamine (spermidine and spermine) content, suggesting improved salt stress resistance.
population_specificity: Peanut (Arachis hypogaea L.) seedlings and transgenic tobacco lines.
effective_dosage: 150 mM NaCl treatment (not a dosage of S-adenosylmethionine itself).
study_duration: Observations were made at 24, 72, and 96 hours post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) on the trans-sulfuration pathway in astrocytes and neurons under Aβ-induced oxidative stress and its protective role in Alzheimer's disease (AD).
results_summary: SAM rescued low trans-sulfuration pathway activity induced by Aβ in astrocytes, increasing cysteine and glutathione levels. It reversed neuronal viability decline caused by Aβ when co-cultured with SAM-treated astrocytes and improved cognitive performance in APP/PS1 mice.
population_specificity: APP/PS1 transgenic mice, primary cultured astrocytes, neurons, and HT22 cells.
